Food is awesome! But service hell noooo! Terrible!
I was waiting for pick up so long and also women who works there was rude!

"The Pilgrim" gourmet pizza!! I hope they keep this on the menu year round, and it is not just seasonal. Tangy goat cheese and cranberry sauce with whole berries, sweet red peppers, turkey (or ham), and other cheeses. Total yum-fest. I keep coming back, and the pizzas are consistently fantastic.

So, a co-worker of mine said that she had a taste for "pide" and would I like to join her for lunch.  To myself, "Um, what the heck is "pide"?  However, I told her, "Yes, that sounds pretty good".  So down the street and around the corner and into a building tucked away on Fourth Street, Downtown, we go!  After giving the secret handshake and being sworn to silence, we enter what looks like a vacant space and order "pide" (Turkish pizza).  OMG!  Who knew that anything like Turkish pizza existed?  It was so tasty!

Pide does not look like pizza; Shaped like a flat football with pinched ends and filled with eggs, cheese and spinach, it was unusual but wonderful.  My co-worker, who frequently eats vegetarian meals turned me on to this and I couldn't thank her enough.
Since the pide was so tasty, I decided to try one of the Ephesus gourmet pizzas with kebabs.  You can order either chicken or lamb kebobs and I ordered half of each on my pizza.  I thought that they would slice the kebab meat and stick on the pizza, but no!  Each slice has its own kebab!  Yippee Skippee!  The best way to eat it is to hold the skewer inside the slice and then wrap the pizza slice around the kebab meat.  Mmmm Mmmm Good!

Ephesus' Downtown Pittsburgh location has since moved closer to PPG Plaza and more easily accessible, which is a good thing.  They also now have a location in Aspinwall which is closer to my home and boy am I glad.  I took a friend visiting from out of town there and he ordered the Moroccan Spiced Chicken and Dried Plum pizza.  I would have never associated those ingredients with pizza, but they were tasty too!

Don't go there looking for fawning service or an elaborate atmosphere...It's not that place.  However, if you want to try delicious pizza with unusual toppings and an excellent crust, this is your place!

Got delivery. Took an 1 hour 40 minutes to arrive (they said it would be about 40).   No apology when I called in to ask about the wait, and also got attitude from the delivery guy. The pita I got was half-cold and stale. The gyro was plain and didn't have a ton of flavor. If I was eating there and the food was fresh it might get 3 stars, but the delivery experience was pretty bad.

I adore Ephesus.  Super under-rated.  It's a pizza place with a Turkish background so in addition to making some pretty decent pizza, they serve traditional turkish/middle- eastern fare like kefta, falafel, baba, hummus- and its really good!

Their Adana Koeffte platter is to die for.  And I just tried a new item yesterday called a "pide" (pe-day)- its a "turkish pizza" (shaped kinda like a football with a thinner, different "crust") topped with ground spiced meat, diced tomato, spinach, cheeses- I lost my mind, it was amazing.  I am going back later this week to get another.  maybe two!

Oh, and they deliver!  to half the city!  I don't even have to leave my house!

If you haven't tried their meat lovers pizza... you need to it's very flavorful. Also the Anatolian Salad is very good...very similar to a Greek salad but they use Turkish dressing. The ranch dressing is homemade and if you like ranch with your pizza you're going to love it.

'Twas a bleak Friday evening for pizza options. Krazy Brothers is gone. Slice on Broadway is terrific, but we'd ordered from them a few times already. The same holds true with Molly's. A scan of our local Pennysaver tabloid turned up no new pizza restaurants that would come to Beechview. 

I remembered a restaurant in Downtown Pittsburgh, one I visited between 3 and 4 years ago that had a magnificent menu and whose couriers seemingly knew no bounds. I nervously made the call, asked, and waited for 30 seconds that felt like 30 hours. 

"Yes. We can come to Beechview."

As I discussed in my previous review, Ephesus has a prolific bill of fare that includes Turkish and Greek specialties in addition to the typical Italian and American items one would expect to find. 

Craving something offbeat, I decided to go for the Pide Deluxe, a Turkish pie featuring that same crispy (fried?) pita-ish crust and the trio of cheeses I relished on that blustery November day. Topping this exotic cruiser of a pizza was Soujcuk, a Turkish pepperoni, a beef salami, tomatoes, green peppers, grilled hot peppers, and mushrooms. 

The pizza itself was served in a manner that was almost deconstructed, coming to our house in a container in what appeared to be New York-style sidewalk slices, yet the pie would be collapsible still, cut in such a way that the crust pulled away in strips. The pepperoni was pungent, its aridity countered by the juicy tomatoes and oily salami. The hot peppers and green peppers nearly cancelled each other out, the mushrooms stepping in to make a case for fungi to be as mightily meaty as steak. 

Kay chose the Moroccan Spiced Chicken and Dry Plum pizza which showcased toppings that appeared to be less random and more deliberate in their layering. The plump chicken was complimented by both the natural sugars of the plum and the sun-dried tomatoes, As the mozzarella/provolone mix cut the spiciness down a notch, gorgonzola turned the brackish volume knob to 6 o' clock. Roasted almonds added textural heft while a bed of fresh spinach made the affair somewhat healthful, lessening the guilt. 

The falafel was dangerously close to being overdone, but those chickpea patties would not allow a few too many seconds in the deep-fryer to deny them their glory, particularly when they were imbibed with onion, garlic, and parsley.

Dessert for me were the Apple Bites, tiny parcels of apple pie filling that were dusted with cinnamon and were somehow held together by the daintiest of crusts. 

Kay wanted the Rice Pudding, but since Ephesus was out of it for the evening, she settled on those fabulous Cinnamon Sticks, and after having a couple, it was evident that they remain the best I've indulged on to date. 

We were told that delivery would take an hour, but our food arrived in half the time and lost none of its warmth in transit. 

With such a broad menu, delivery range, and hours of operation, Ephesus Pizza is not just a neighborhood pizza joint; they are a cosmopolitan restaurant that efficiently services a metropolitan area and does it proud. Visitors stuck in a local hotel would do well to place an order tonight.

Stopped in to get a gyro.  Friendly service and somehow related to the location on 4th downtown.  The menu has some variety from Wraps & Gyro's to Pide (Turkish Pizza) to kebaps, to regular pizza, salads and wings.  

My gyro was good.  The fries were pretty good too.  Will have to stop back and try a Pide.  The person next to us had a Pide and said it was his favorite thing on the menu.

This place used to be awesome. I don't know if they're under new management lately or what, but the last couple experiences were not good. Their regular pizza tastes like bad grade school cafeteria pizza. Their white pizza is soggy, greasy, undercooked and the veggies are wilted, sloppy and pathetic, nowhere near as fresh as they once were. The time I got chicken carbonara, it tasted like someone poured hot 2% milk over noodles- runny and flavorless. The only thing that saves this place are their breakfast pizzas. They are pretty sweet. But considering the last 3+ times I've ordered, the wait has been over an hour and a half, not even breakfast pizza will bring me back. Oh, and their one delivery guy is SUPER creepy to girls with tattoos.
OMG amazing pizza! I had the Lamb Kebob small and am blown away!  I can't believe I hadn't bound this hidden treasure sooner!
Terrible.  You're better off picking up a frozen pie from your local grocery store.  I can't wait for Aladdins to open a downtown location.

Although it's called "Mediterranean," and there is indeed falafel on the menu (if you can find it), Ephesus clearly specializes in pizza. And, apparently, delivery. I walked in, and I think it took three minutes of confused questioning on both my part and the cashier's to communicate that I was placing an order, not picking one up. It also could have been my imagination, but I think I got a quizzical look for getting something other than pizza. It's not an attractive place to hang out, so it's no wonder delivery is their thing.

I got a falafel wrap with a side of fries. The veggies on the wrap were lackluster, though the falafel and pita were acceptable. I was given a little cup of some kind of sauce, but what I really would have liked on it was hummus. I wouldn't be surprised if they'd provide it if asked, but it's not there by default.

It was all kind of meh to me. I'll give the benefit of the doubt and suppose their pizza is better, but if "Mediterranean Kitchen" makes up two-thirds of the name, you expect the falafel to be more than just acceptable.

Emphasis never disappoints the pizza is always fresh and cheesy. They're quick and efficient so you never wait more than 15/20 min for food when doing pick up. Huge fan of the specialty pizzas which are always packed with delicious fresh ingredients. 
Most recently I got a large Hesse pizza and Italian hoagie. Both were delicious- pizza was cheesy with just the right amount of sauce and the hoagie was toasted but not so much so that your couldn't enjoy the contents

The pizza is healthier than usual pizza. The one we got wasn't really greasy but the pizza itself was ridiculously thin and all of the toppings fell right off. Personally if I'm going to get pizza I'm going to go to papa johns. I prefer toppings to stay on it

The other reviews are spot on about the ambiance.  It's very frat house chic, with lots of crappy fourth hand furniture, flickering fluorescent lights and turkish news playing on the the big screen TV (WTF?) 

It is a bitch to find, especially at night, so pack your gps.  Once you find the building, you have to punch in the code ( It was 0002 when I went) for the door to get into the lobby at least at night.  Once you're in the lobby, you have to go to the elevator and hit "M"  for mezzanine level.  There was no sign telling us to do that and the elevator wouldn't let us select any other floor without a security badge, so it took us a little while to figure out.  Once we stepped off the elevator, my friend was having serious second thoughts about the place because of the sketchy vibe, but I'm glad we stayed because the food was REALLY REALLY good.  

I got a meat lovers pizza that was absolutely piled with pepperoni, sausage, ham,  and bacon.  It was really tasty.  My friend got the Lamb Shish Kabob which had some sort of magical spices on it.  It was like a circus in your mouth.  It also came with some kind of flat bread with sesame seeds which was really good.  

The location (second floor, over the river and through the woods)  and the atmosphere absolutely suck, but the food definitely didn't disappoint. I knocked off 1 star for sketchiness, but the place redeemed itself when our order came out.  If this place found a  little nicer location on street level, it would own.

I do not know which is worse, the delivery, the cold food, or the lack of customer service. Lost the business of a customer who has given  $300 of business in a day with a who cares attitude. This place sucks!

90 minutes for two cold pizzas.....sorry at this point even a two star review is generous.

While in town with friends, we wanted an easy meal after running the half marathon earlier in the day.  Consulting Yelp, I saw that this place had good reviews, they delivered and since we were less than a mile from them, we figured we'd have the food fairly fast (there were two hungry toddlers and five hungry adults, and we needed food, stat!)

Upon calling, we first asked if they delivered to hotels just to be sure.  If they didn't, that would be fine we'd call someplace else.  So we ordered our two pizzas and gave them the name and address of the hotel. It is a newish hotel, so I told my buddy to tell them "It's right by the Consol Energy Center, where the Penguins play".  I figured that even if they didn't know the hotel or the address, most people in Pittsburgh would know where the Penguins play.  We were concerned when we had to say the name of the hotel four times and as it turned out, we were right to be concerned.

After an hour with no pizzas, we call and they guy says "Oh, the delivery guy is on your street right now.  Should be 2 minutes".  20 minutes later the delivery guy calls and says he's on his way.  We ask if he knows where he's going and he says yes.  10 minutes later he calls again and asks where we are.  When we finally got the pizza, it was not hot.  The cheese had congealed everywhere and it looked like it had been cut by a toddler.  There were so big slices, some little slices...just not the usual uniform slices.

I felt bad for the guy because he said his GPS had been stolen that morning, but we tried everything to make sure that the place new we were at the hotel right beside the arena and it still failed.  

Better luck next time.

This pizza is BY FAR the best pizza in Pittsburgh. Yes, I said it. Over Fiori's. Over Beto's. Over Stone. I could go on....

We order from here at work frequently and have never been disappointed with the food. The pizza is the perfect amount of dough-y and cheesy and cooked to delightfulness. I would love to try some of their other national dishes on the menu. The only thing that could definitely change is notifying customers of when their order will be late. Twice so far I haven't been notified when the delivery time is over 45 minutes. Hungry workers would at least like a heads up!

Difficult to find...take the elevator up to the M level.  
No decor inside...feels like an old cafeteria, and the location sucks, but the food is really good...it would do amazingly well in a better location.
I went for a workday lunch; very good menu and my friend raved about their Turkish pizza.  I'd recommend ordering online/ordering before you go, or else you might wait a little while.  I got their grilled chicken salad and the chicken they had on it was some of the best I've had downtown.

This is the cheesiest,most delicious, gooey wonderful pizza I've had in a long time. After trying all the pizza joints A-wall has to offer, I think I have found my go-to. We also got some expertly-done wings. Not dry, not soggy, just enough crispyness. 

Their menu also includes some really delicious-looking specialty pizzas I can't wait to try.

Ephesus is special.  Fast friendly service.  Surprisingly comfy and stylish seating and lighting for a primarily take out shop.  A broad, customizable menu with a solid mix of Italian and Greek deliciousness.  Low prices, massive portions, and better prepared, home made, flavorful food than they have any right to offer at the prices they charge.  

Ephesus is not a 5 star culinary experience, but for the casual fare and reasonable rates they offer, I can't imagine a better choice.  Well done Ephesus, you set the bar for all other local delivery spots to try to live up to!
